title: 105_hr1465
content: Restoration of deduction for interest on educational loans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 restores the deduction for interest on educational loans, defining a qualified educational loan as any indebtedness provided through a guarantee program. A qualified educational loan can be provided through a guarantee program, by a tax-exempt organization, or by a financial institution under a supplemental education program. The loan must be used to pay for qualified educational expenses within a reasonable timeframe. The tax benefit for interest on qualified educational loans is phased out based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The reduction in the amount of interest taken into account is determined by the ratio of the taxpayer's income over a certain threshold to the phaseout range. The tax deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is phased out based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The applicable dollar amounts and phaseout ranges vary depending on filing status. The deduction is only allowable for the first 48 months of repayment. The tax deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. Qualified educational expenses include tuition and related expenses for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent. The tax deduction for interest on qualified educational loans includes reasonable living expenses while away from home. The $40,000 and $60,000 amounts in the deduction are adjusted for inflation annually. The tax deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is adjusted annually for inflation. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997, with respect to loans with the first required payment after that date.
